A. J. MCAULEY
SELF-CONFIGURING NETWORKS
K. MANOUSAKIS
TELCORDIA
445 SOUTH STREET, MORRISTOWN, NJ 07960
ABSTRACT*
To make future tactical battlefield networks more flexible
and robust, nodes must rapidly configure themselves with
little or no human intervention and reconfigure
automatically as the environment changes. This paper
describes the Dynamic Registration and Configuration
Protocol (DRCP) and Dynamic Address Allocation
Protocol (DAAP) that together can provide true stateless
autoconfiguration of an entire network domain. We first
describe DRCE which extends DHCP into new domains
such as wireless networks and commercial service
providers. We then describe DAAP, which distributes
addresses and other configuration parameters to DRCP
servers. Although kept much simpler by relying on DRCE
we show DAAP must still be carefully designed to ensure
robustness while maintaining enough address hierarchy to
reduce routing protocol overhead. Implementations of
DRCP and DAAP on a Linux PC platform are described.

1. INTRODUCTION
Most applications use the TCP/IP Internet Protocol suite to
provide robust communication over heterogeneous
network technologies. With the growth in networked
devices and wireless access technology, these networks are
becoming more complex and malleable. Although the
mobility is largely confined to roaming hosts in the
commercial domain, battlefield networks will be
characterized by high mobility, not only of leaf nodes but
also of whole networks. Whole networks (e.g., of sensors)
may need to be rapidly deployed. Nodes may continuously
move and may appear for short periods of time and then
disappear. The result is a more dynamic network.
At one extreme, networks will constantly change shape
and have little structure. Here addressing can be flat and
routing done using an ad-hoc (MANET) routing or simply

highly stable, with only leaf nodes (hosts) moving. Here,
router addresses can be manually configured to reflect the
fixed hierarchy and routing can be done using
conventional routing protocols. In between, however, there
are many quasi-dynamic networks.
There are many examples of quasi-dynamic networks. A
dynamically deployed sensor array, for example, may
require rapid deployment; but be relatively stable except
for some incremental deployment and losses. A fast
moving platoon might constantly change its attachment
point to the rest of the Brigade, but its elements may be
fairly constant. An airbome communication node may
move over the battlefield and provide support to different
elements, but remain "fixed" for hours at a time.
Quasi-dynamic networks present challenges for
registration, configuration, address binding and routing.
This paper is concerned with registration and
autoconfiguration in these quasi-dynamic networks, which
we believe, are functions that should be tied together. It
does not discuss binding, and routing protocols, which we
believe should be independent of autoconfiguration.
Our goal is that all host and routers in the quasi-dynamic
domain will be plug and play. Nodes register then self-
configure, with little or no human intervention; moreover,
the nodes reconfigure automatically as network topology
changes. The only restriction on the number of nodes
would be the size of the address space. If achieved this
would not only reduce management nightmares, but allow
far greater mobility to battlefield nodes without causing:
a) routing protocols to blow-up, b) single points of failure
(servers), or c) forcing tunneling overhead on all users.
Section 2 describes existing approaches to registration and
configuration. Section 3 and describe the Dynamic
Registration and Configuration Protocol (DRCP) that
extends DHCP for new environments and Dynamic
Address Allocation Protocol (DAAP) which distributes
addresses within a domain. Section 5 describes the
combination of DRCP and DAAP for complete network
autoconfiguration. Finally, Section 6 compares our
approach to other approaches.
2. REGISTRATION AND CONFIGURATION
This section describes several protocol used Today for
registration and autoconfiguration. We define these
functions as follows:
Registration: A network checks a client's credentials
and either allows or disallows them into the network.
Configuration: A network provides client's
information to adapt then to network characteristics,
such a fully qualified IP address, domain name, and
addresses of the first-hop and local DNS server.
We believe these two functions should be combined,
because they both must be done before a node can send
packets. Other functions should be separate either because
they either do not involve clients (e.g., routing and access
control) or should be optional (e.g., locating a node).
2.1 PPP
The most common protocol client's use for registration
and configuration is the Point to Point Protocol (PPP) [l].
The client sends registration information, such as login
and password to an access concentrator on the Layer 2
network to which the client is connected. The access
concentrator then configures the client. Layer Two
Tunneling Protocol (L2TP) can tunnel PPP packets from
the concentrator to a server anywhere in the Intemet [2].
While PPP is a good for serial links, such as phone lines, it
is not ideal for networks that frame packets, such as
Ethernet. While protocols can allow PPP over anything
(e.g., PPPoE [3]), they leave much unnecessary overhead
(2 bytes for framing, 2 bytes for CRC, up to 4 other bytes,
and bit or byte stuffing overhead).
2.2 Mobile IP
Mobile IP is a simple and scalable solution to manage
device mobility throughout the global Intemet [4]. A
Home Agent provides the dynamic binding function that
redirects messages to the roaming users' latest location. In
addition the Foreign Agent supports host registration and
configuration, especially when combined with recent
enhancements [5] [6] [7].
Mobile IP provides networks transparency above the IP
layer. Although this transparency is ideal for many
applications (e.g., TCP applications such as telnet or ftp),
this functionality is not always needed (e.g., for web
browsing) or may be better provided by alternative
mechanism (viz., SIP for real-time applications). Given its
costs (e.g., triangular routing) and need for Foreign
Agents, we believe Mobile IP should not be required in the
battlefield environment; rather we believe Mobile IP is
best used selectively and in pop-up mode.

2.3DHCP
The Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP)
provides a framework for host registration and
configuration [XI. DHCP has many desirable features,
including: a) worhng on any wired or wireless network, b)
no manual configuration, c) direct routing, d) choice of
dynamic binding protocol, e) allowing nodes to go on and
off without re-registration, and f) allowing a single
network server per domain (using relay agents). DHCP is
likely to continue to gain in popularity with recent
enhancements, such as: authentication [9], dynamic
updating of DNS [lo], LDAP database management [ll],
load balancing [ 121 and server fail-over [13].
3. DRCP
The Dynamic Registration and Configuration Protocol
(DRCP) is designed to be a general-purpose, stand-alone
protocol that supports node configuration.
3.1 Added Features
While DRCP borrows heavily from DHCP, it adds many
new features created by new environments [19]:
Rapid configuration (milliseconds not seconds).
Efficient use of scarce wirelesses bandwidth.
Rapid client detection of need to reconfigure.
Allowing clients to be routers.
Dynamic serverhelay "pre-configuration".
Leightweight (no added functions).
DHCP specification [8] says a client SHOULD do ARP
checking before an assigned address is used. This "in-line"
checking results in long delay (typically 3-15 seconds)
before communication can resume after a move; too long
for many roaming users. DHCP message size and number
of messages are also much larger than needed. This wastes
valuable bandwidth.
DHCP provides no mechanism to detect a need to change
configuration. Hosts must rely on external mechanisms,
such as a layer 2 hand-off indication. These triggers are
not always available, however, and do not distinguish
between movement within a subnet and among subnets. A
platoon in a battlefield, for example, may need to be
reconfigured when it moves relative to the rest of the
brigade. DHCP also says that client nodes must be a host.
Like DHCP, however, DRCP remains focused solely on
configuration. Other protocols must provide features such
as registration, continuous connectivity (e.g., [4] [ l SI),
inter-domain AAA ([ 151 [ 161 [20]), or address distribution
(See Section 4).

DRCP, nor DRCP, provides registration capabilities.
Battlefield networks need a scalable way to identify (e.g.,
[14]) and authenticate users and perform other registration
functions. DRCP, however, does provide the address of the
registration agent that will perform node authentication,
authorization, and accounting (AAA) protocol [ 151 [ 161
3.2DRCPMessages
Most messages have the same basic semantics as those
used in DHCP; however, many have extended
functionality. There are five messages from a client:
DISCOVER: Client requests an address and/or other
configuration parameters.
ACCEPT: Client accepts offered parameters from one
server and implicitly declining offers from all others.
DECLINE: Client refuses offered parameters (e.g.,
because the service offered is unacceptable).
REQUEST: Client confirms correctness of previously
allocated address and/or other service parameters.
RELEASE: De-registration message sent by a client
on its local subnet to cancel a remaining lease.

3.3 Operation
DRCP uses a client-server model. The client is similar to a
DHCP-client, except that it can lie on a host or a router. A
server is similar to the DHCP-server leasing addresses
from its pool to clients within its domain. Each domain
must have at least one server, but multiple servers can be
used for fault tolerance..
If a client has just been rebooted, moves to a new domain,
or just wants to extend a lease, then there may be a flow of
messages such as that shown in Figure 1. Here, the server
initiates periodic ADVERTISEMENT messages (these
messages are optional). The client transmits and
retransmits DISCOVER (or REQUEST) messages until it
gets an OFFER (or ACK). The server transmits and
retransmits the OFFER (or ACK) until it gets an ACCEPT
or DECLINE.

3.4 Interoperation with DHCP
There is a large paradigm shift from supporting hosts on
physically secure LANs, to supporting roaming hosts and
routers on networks that allow unauthorized access. We
therefore propose a new sister protocol, DRCP, rather than
extending DHCP to eliminate the added complexity of
maintaining compatibility, and allowing protocol
optimization (e.g., minimizing message size).
DRCP can still interoperate with existing DHCP clients
and servers using a dual approach. For example, a client
could have both protocols and use DHCP if a DRCP server
is not available in the subnet.
4. DAAP
This section describes the "Dynamic Address Allocation
Protocol (DAAP) that distributes address-pools (and other
configuration information) among nodes in a domain.

5. DRCPAND DAAP
This section describes how DRCP and DAAP can be
combined to provide autoconfiguration of a domain.
5.1 Functional Split
DAAP has to do with the utilization and distribution of
address pools that are used by configuration protocols
such as DRCP. At the moment, protocols like DHCP and
DRCP require manual distribution of the pools of
available IP addresses. In sense DAAP as a supporting
protocol that can distribute a large pool of available I P
addresses to tens of thousands of nodes and hundred of
subnets without manual intervention.
Section 3 shows that DRCP can only configure an inter-
face if there are DRCP server nodes on the subnet to
which that interface is attached. DRCP, however, allows
the address-pool (and other information such as address of
a central server) to be changed dynamically. A DRCP node
can even go from a client mode to a server after receiving
an address pool. DAAP distributes the address-pools to the
DRCP nodes. DAAP protocol balances these goals:

The level-I master nodes form a second-level cluster,
which elects a second-level master. This process repeats

6.2 Link State
Autoconfiguration can be done after finding out the
topology with a domain. This is a similar idea to a link
state routing protocol, such as OSPF and can potentially
configure nodes even when address space is limited. The
drawback of this approach is the amount of signaling
traffic needed to distribute link state information (a big
problem in battlefield environments where bandwidth may
be scarce and networks may be highly dynamic).
7. CONCLUSION
This paper describes our approach to plug-and-play
operations within a domain. It combines an enhanced
DHCP protocol (DRCP) with an address-pool distribution
protocol (DAAP). The dual protocol approach is attractive
since it allows commercial development of the complex
base protocol (DRCP) [17], leaving a much simpler
protocol (DAAP) for those, such as the military, that need
stateless autoconfiguration of an entire network domain.
Unlike DHCP, on which it is based, DRCP supports many
different network environments: everything from open
dynamic ad-hoc networks to secured, stable tightly
managed high-speed networks. We describe the many
enhancements required to support the new environments.
An initial implementation has been built in user space on a
Linux platform. It has successfully autoconfigured 4 PCs
over two subnets, displaying some of the enhanced
features such fast handoff and router configuration.
As part of an overall solution to the tactical battlefield,
DRCP and DAAP greatly reduces management nightmares
and provides much greater movement flexibility.
Furthermore, it does not cause: a) routing protocols to
blow-up, b) single points of failure (servers), or c)
tunneling overhead on all users. Providing these functions
independently of Mobile IP allows applications to choose
whether to have the overhead or to use a solution better
suited to the environment (e.g., SIP [18]).
